item.feedback: "Guten Tag" (literally, Good day) is used often and works well with people you don't know or don't know very well.
"Hallo" is a preferred greeting among young adults who wish to be casual.
"Guten Morgen" is a standard greeting. Use it until shortly before lunchtime.
"Wie gehts?" (How's it going?) is a rather generic question, but don't be surprised if Germans give a detailed answer when asked this question.
"Guten Abend" is used anytime after 6:00 p.m.
This is used with people who you would address as "Herr" (Mr.) or "Frau" (Mrs.)

item.lang_tl: Mir geht es gut, danke, und wie geht es Ihnen?
item.lang_trans: meer geyt es goot, daanka, unt vee geyt es eenen?
item.feedback: This is a typical answer to someone you know but who is not a friend.
Short and simple - you can't go wrong with this answer.
This question is more suitable for an interview than a friendly chat.
Introducing yourself by your first name is still considered rather casual by older people and traditionalists but is common among the young.
"Angenehm" (Delighted) is a very formal, traditional way of responding when you first meet a stranger.
"Willkommen" is a friendly greeting to visitors.
"Auf Wiedersehen" is a standard way of saying good-bye and appropriate in most social situations.
This phrase assumes that the speakers will indeed see each other again soon, typically on the same day.
This phrase is used when there is a clear understanding that the speakers will see each other the next day.
